flow.context: Ryan Proctor is a Property Manager and Shareholder at Crown Realty Property Management, which runs Crown Vacation Rentals (Napa Vacation Condos) — vacation condo rentals in Napa Valley. He's a U.S. Navy veteran with a process-driven mindset. The company uses Streamline as their PMS (owner portal links to ownerx.streamlinevrs.com). Key ops people below him: Fernanda Navarro (Operations Manager), Janett Sanchez (Maintenance Director), Rebecca Daigle (Property Maintenance Review Coordinator). Sam's strongest hook: he's in the Bay Area regularly (aunt is a VP at Salesforce in SF) and works with other NorCal vacation rental managers.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Ryan — I work with a couple other vacation rental companies up in NorCal, I'm actually in the Bay Area pretty regularly. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Feet-up-on-the-desk energy. Sound like you're calling someone you were supposed to call. Don't rush. Pause after the question.

branches.label: No / Who? / Doesn't ring a bell
Bad timing / I'm busy / In the middle of something
Is this a sales call? / What are you selling?

heard_no.label: HEARD NO — TRANSITION TO PAIN
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I was talking to another vacation rental manager running a pretty similar setup to you guys, condos in wine country, high turnover during peak season. And the thing that kept eating at him was the gap between what his cleaners were photographing during turnovers and what actually got caught. He had a guest check into a unit where a window screen was torn and a couch cushion had a wine stain — both were sitting right there in the turnover photos, but nobody flagged either one. Guest left a two-star review mentioning both. That's the kind of thing that hits you twice — the repair cost plus the review damage.
heard_no.note: PAUSE here. Let Ryan react. Do NOT rush to the solution. You want him to say 'yeah' or 'I hear you' or share his own version of this pain.

branches.label: Yeah we deal with that / That sounds familiar
We've got a pretty good process already
I'm not really the right person for this

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES — EXPLORE
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let them talk. Whatever they say, bridge to pain or discovery depending on how much they know.

branches.label: Vague / Not sure / Just the name

bridge_to_pain.label: BRIDGE TO PAIN TRIGGER
bridge_to_pain.say: Totally fair. The short version — I was talking to another vacation rental manager running condos in wine country, similar setup to you guys. And the thing that kept coming up was turnover photos. His team was taking hundreds of photos every turnover, but stuff was still slipping through — stains, damage, missing items. A guest checked in, found a torn screen and a stained cushion, left a two-star review. Both issues were in the photos. Nobody caught them.
bridge_to_pain.note: Pause after this. Let him react naturally before you go anywhere.

branches.label: Yeah that happens / We've seen that
We've got a handle on that
What do you do about it?

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow or later this week?
bad_timing.note: Don't over-apologize. Quick, easy, respectful. Lock a callback if possible.

lock_callback.label: LOCK CALLBACK TIME
lock_callback.say: Perfect — I've got tomorrow morning pulled up. Would around ten work, or is afternoon better for you?
lock_callback.note: Give two options. Lock a specific time, not 'sometime this week.'

confirm_callback.label: CONFIRM CALLBACK
confirm_callback.say: Got it — I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Ryan.
confirm_callback.note: Short and clean. Don't add more info. Lock it and hang up.

caught_as_cold_call.label: PERMISSION ASK
caught_as_cold_call.say: Yeah totally — it is a cold call. Can I get thirty seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
caught_as_cold_call.note: Disarm with honesty. Most people will give you 30 seconds if you're upfront about it.

branches.label: No / Not interested / Take me off your list

permission_rejected.label: LAST CHANCE SPLIT
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it more that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This splits their reason. 'Bad time' reopens the door for a callback. 'Not interesting' means you exit clean.

branches.label: Bad time / Just busy right now

pain_landed.label: PAIN LANDED — DELIVER SOLUTION
pain_landed.say: Yeah, that's exactly what we keep hearing. So we built an AI that plugs into the turnover photos your team's already taking — I know you guys are on Streamline — and it automatically flags damage, stains, missing items, staging issues before the next guest checks in. No workflow change, it just reads the photos you already have.
pain_landed.note: One sentence on the solution. Reference Streamline to show you did homework. Then pause and let him take it wherever he wants. Don't over-explain.

branches.label: That's interesting / How does that work?
We already have something for that

solution_sentence.label: SOLUTION SENTENCE
solution_sentence.say: So the short version — we built an AI that plugs into the turnover photos your team's already taking and automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues before the next guest walks in. It works with Streamline, which I know you guys use. No workflow change on your end.
solution_sentence.note: Keep it tight. One breath. Then pause and see where he takes it.

branches.label: We're fine with our current process

discovery_warm.label: DISCOVERY — THEY'RE WARM
discovery_warm.say: Appreciate you hearing me out. I'm curious — what does your turnover process look like right now? Are your cleaners taking photos after every turn, or is it more of a spot-check kind of thing?
discovery_warm.note: STOP PITCHING. They're interested — now learn. Ask about their process, not their problems. Listen for: who takes photos, how many, who reviews them, what falls through the cracks.

branches.label: Describes their process / Cleaners take photos
Fernanda or Janett handles that / The ops team does
We don't really do formal inspections

discovery_deeper.label: DEEPER DISCOVERY
discovery_deeper.say: Got it. And who's typically reviewing those photos after the turn — is that you, or does that fall on someone like your ops team or maintenance crew?
discovery_deeper.note: You're mapping their org. If Rebecca Daigle (Maintenance Review Coordinator) or Fernanda Navarro (Operations Manager) reviews photos, that's gold — RapidEye replaces that manual review. Get the name.

branches.label: Our ops manager / maintenance team handles it

discovery_volume.label: DISCOVERY — VOLUME AND PAIN
discovery_volume.say: How many units are you guys turning over in a typical week during peak season? And what percentage of those photos would you say actually get a real look versus just getting filed away?
discovery_volume.note: You're quantifying the problem. More units + lower review rate = bigger pain. This data also helps you tailor the demo. If he says a high number of units and low review rate, that's your opening to book.

branches.label: Shares numbers / Admits low review rate
I'm not sure of exact numbers

streamline_angle.label: STREAMLINE INTEGRATION ANGLE
streamline_angle.say: That's solid. One thing I'm curious about — since you guys are on Streamline, are you running PropertyCare for your inspections, or is it more manual than that?
streamline_angle.note: This probes their actual workflow depth on Streamline. If they use PropertyCare, RapidEye can layer on top. If they don't, there's an even bigger gap. Either answer leads to the meeting.

branches.label: No / We don't use that piece
I'm not sure what we use exactly

no_formal_process.label: NO FORMAL PROCESS — OPPORTUNITY
no_formal_process.say: That's actually super common — most vacation rental managers we talk to are in the same boat. The photos exist, they're just sitting there. That's kind of the whole point of what we built — it turns those photos into actual actionable reports without anyone having to manually go through them. Would you be open to me showing you what that looks like? Not a big production — fifteen minutes, I can walk you through what we're doing with a couple other NorCal managers.
no_formal_process.note: This is your strongest position — they have photos but no system. Frame the meeting as low-commitment and peer-oriented.

branches.label: I'd need to loop in my ops team

cta_soft.label: SOFT CTA
cta_soft.say: Would you be open to seeing how it works? I could walk you through what a couple other vacation rental managers in NorCal are doing with their turnover photos — worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
cta_soft.note: Low pressure. 'Worst case you steal some ideas' takes the commitment out of it.

branches.label: I don't think this is for us
I'd need to talk to someone else first

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with a vacation rental operation in Napa you'd have to have something dialed in. I'd honestly expect that. Just out of curiosity — is it that your current process is catching everything and you're fully happy, or is it more that changing anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: Agree first. Then split it. 'Fully happy' is rare — most people will admit something slips. 'Headache to change' opens the door for the no-workflow-change angle.

branches.label: It's fine / We're happy / It works
Switching anything is a pain / Locked in

objection_have_vendor.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A VENDOR
objection_have_vendor.say: That makes total sense — you'd have to have something in place. Totally respect that. Is it that you're fully covered and happy with it, or is it more that switching anything right now would be a headache?
objection_have_vendor.note: Same split. Don't ask what vendor — that's combative. Let them volunteer it.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have
Switching is the issue / Too much going on
It's okay but not perfect / Stuff still slips

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it. I probably should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that turnover quality just isn't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls?
objection_not_interested.note: Lighten it up with the cold call line. If they say 'not focused on it,' that's a timing or priority issue — either can reopen. If they laugh about cold calls, you've got another shot.

branches.label: Just not focused on it right now

no_workflow_change.label: NO WORKFLOW CHANGE PITCH
no_workflow_change.say: Totally hear you. That's actually the main reason people end up taking the call — there's literally no workflow change. It reads the photos your team's already uploading to Streamline. Nobody does anything different. It just catches what humans miss. You're probably not buying anything right now and I respect that — but would you be open to a fifteen-minute look so it's on your radar when you're ready?
no_workflow_change.note: The 'no workflow change' angle is your strongest card against switching pain. Then frame the meeting as future-proofing, not buying.

test_drive_pitch.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
test_drive_pitch.say: Totally respect that. You're probably not buying anything today, and I get it. But when budget or timing does open up, the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's on their list. Would you be open to a quick look — not for now, just so you know it exists? If nothing else, I can show you what a couple other NorCal vacation rental managers are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas.
test_drive_pitch.note: Frame it as zero-commitment intelligence gathering. 'Steal some ideas' is disarming. Ryan is a shareholder — appeal to the business upside of being ahead of the curve.

deflect_price.label: DEFLECT PRICE QUESTION
deflect_price.say: Honestly it depends on the setup — number of units, how many turnovers you're running, what you're using today. That's part of why it'd be worth a quick call where I can actually tailor it. Would you be open to fifteen minutes later this week?
deflect_price.note: Never quote price on a cold call. Redirect to the meeting. Price questions are buying signals — they're interested enough to ask.

deflect_price_again.label: DEFLECT PRICE — SECOND ASK
deflect_price_again.say: I hear you — I don't want to throw a number out that's totally off base because it really does depend on your volume. But I can tell you we're working with managers running anywhere from twenty to six hundred properties, so we're built to scale to wherever you're at. Let me put fifteen minutes on the calendar and I'll come with numbers specific to your setup. How's later this week look?
deflect_price_again.note: Give a range signal without committing. Then redirect firmly to the meeting.

referral_to_ops.label: REFERRAL — GET TO OPS TEAM
referral_to_ops.say: Totally makes sense — who on your team typically owns the turnover and inspection workflow? Is that Fernanda or someone on the maintenance side?
referral_to_ops.note: You know Fernanda Navarro is Ops Manager and Janett Sanchez is Maintenance Director. Drop Fernanda's name naturally — shows homework and makes it easy for Ryan to confirm or redirect. If he mentions Rebecca Daigle (Maintenance Review Coordinator), that's your bullseye.

branches.label: Yeah Fernanda / Yes the ops team
I can handle it / Loop me in

ask_for_intro.label: ASK FOR INTRO
ask_for_intro.say: Would you be open to connecting me? I can put together something specific so it actually lands with them and doesn't feel like a random cold pitch. Or if it's easier, I'm happy to just mention your name when I reach out.
ask_for_intro.note: Give Ryan two options: warm intro (ideal) or permission to name-drop (still great). Either one turns your next call warm.

branches.label: I'll pass it along / Let me talk to them
Yeah you can mention my name
Just reach out to them directly

confirm_referral_followup.label: CONFIRM REFERRAL — THEY'LL PASS IT
confirm_referral_followup.say: Really appreciate that, Ryan. I'll shoot you a quick email at rproctor at crownpm — that still the best one? — with a short summary so you've got something to forward. And if it makes sense to get all three of us on a quick call, I'm happy to set that up too.
confirm_referral_followup.note: Confirm the email. Offer to set up the three-way call to keep momentum. Don't over-ask — he's already helping you.

confirm_referral_namedrop.label: CONFIRM REFERRAL — NAME DROP
confirm_referral_namedrop.say: Perfect — I'll reach out to them and mention we chatted. Appreciate you pointing me in the right direction, Ryan. If it ever circles back to you, I'm easy to find.
confirm_referral_namedrop.note: Clean exit. You got what you need — a name drop and direction. Follow up within 24 hours before the goodwill fades.

not_right_person.label: NOT THE RIGHT PERSON
not_right_person.say: Totally hear you — who on your team would typically own the inspection and turnover workflow? I want to make sure I'm reaching the right person.
not_right_person.note: Don't argue. Pivot to referral immediately. Ryan is a shareholder so even if he's not hands-on with turnovers, his referral carries serious weight internally.

branches.label: Gives a name / Points to ops or maintenance

suggest_ops_names.label: SUGGEST OPS NAMES
suggest_ops_names.say: No worries. I saw Fernanda Navarro's name come up as your operations manager — would she be the right person? Or would it be more on the maintenance side with Janett?
suggest_ops_names.note: Giving names makes it easy for Ryan to just confirm rather than think. Don't list more than two — it starts to feel creepy.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Perfect — I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up. What's easier for you, morning or afternoon?
book_meeting.note: Lock it NOW. Give two days, let them pick the time. Send the calendar invite while you're still on the phone. Stop pitching — you've won.

branches.label: Let me check my calendar / I'll get back to you

book_meeting_with_context.label: BOOK MEETING — WITH CONTEXT
book_meeting_with_context.say: This is really helpful, Ryan. I think the most useful thing would be for me to show you exactly how this works with your setup — Streamline, your turnover volume, all of it. I can make it specific to you. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday open — which works better?
book_meeting_with_context.note: You've gathered discovery intel. Use it to make the meeting pitch feel tailored, not generic. Lock the time now.

branches.label: Let me check / I'll get back to you

pin_down_meeting.label: PIN DOWN THE MEETING
pin_down_meeting.say: Totally — how about I send over a couple options and you grab whichever works? What's your best email — still rproctor at crownpm?
pin_down_meeting.note: Don't let it float. Send options immediately. Confirm the email so you have a direct line for follow-up.

confirm_meeting.label: CONFIRM AND CLOSE
confirm_meeting.say: Awesome — I'll send that invite right over. Really appreciate you taking my call, Ryan. Talk to you then.
confirm_meeting.note: STOP SELLING. You got the meeting. Confirm, be grateful, hang up. Send the invite within 60 seconds.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question so I don't send you a generic pitch that goes straight to trash — what would be most relevant to include? Is it more about how it works with your current setup, or more about what other vacation rental managers are seeing in terms of results?
send_email.note: Accept the email request but ask one question to tailor it. This keeps the conversation going and shows you care about relevance.

branches.label: Results / ROI / What others are seeing

confirm_email_send.label: CONFIRM EMAIL AND SUGGEST TIME
confirm_email_send.say: Got it — I'll send that over to rproctor at crownpm today. I'll include a couple times to connect in case you want to dig in after reading it. Appreciate your time, Ryan.
confirm_email_send.note: Confirm their email. Send it within the hour. Include 2-3 specific time slots in the email. Follow up in 2 days if no response.

thank_and_close.label: THANK AND CLOSE
thank_and_close.say: Perfect. Really appreciate it, Ryan. I'll get that over to you today. Talk soon.
thank_and_close.note: Send the email within 30 minutes. Keep it short, specific, and include a summary they can easily forward to their ops team.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand, Ryan. If anything changes, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Short, respectful, done. Log the outcome and set a reminder to try again in 3-4 weeks via a different channel.
